On my screen I have the candidate packet for Alex Chen: resume, interview scorecards, technical assessment breakdown (with a couple of flagged areas where they missed some edge cases), and short writeups from each interviewer. I also have an internal leveling guide open in another tab—what we expect from someone with ~5 years’ experience, what “Senior” means at our company versus at a startup, and the compensation bands approved for Austin-based roles (base salary ranges, target bonus, and equity guidelines). A spreadsheet from finance is open with our current headcount plan and budget constraints for this quarter, plus a view of recent accepted offers so we don’t create internal inequity.

The atmosphere is practical and a little time-pressured: we want to close the role soon, but we’re also trying to be consistent with our comp philosophy and avoid overcorrecting based on any single data point. There’s a notepad beside me with a few bullets: “strong problem-solving,” “communication gaps—manageable with support,” “hybrid Austin,” “assessment 78/100,” and reminders to align the offer to the role’s scope and our leveling rubric rather than anchoring too heavily on any prior salary figure.

The interview day itself is a mix of in-person and Zoom. After the interviews, the panel debrief happens in a different glass room with a speakerphone in the middle of the table. Recruiting joins for part of the meeting to cover logistics: hybrid expectations in Austin, pay bands, and internal equity constraints. Someone mentions that the company has been careful about comp alignment lately—offers need to fit a defined range and not create compression with current senior engineers.

Finally, the compensation decision is made at the manager’s desk later that afternoon: they pull up a compensation tool showing Austin pay bands for the level, recent offers, and where current team members sit. They consider how Alex’s strengths map to the role (high execution, strong debugging/problem-solving) and where they might need support (stakeholder communication, clearer written updates). The manager aims for an offer that is competitive for Austin, consistent with the company’s leveling, and defensible internally—more like a calibrated “best fair offer” than a negotiation anchored to any single data point.
